"Then, turning to his disciples, Jesus said, “That is why I tell you not to worry about everyday life—whether you have enough food to eat or enough clothes to wear. For life is more than food, and your body more than clothing. Look at the ravens. They don’t plant or harvest or store food in barns, for God feeds them. And you are far more valuable to him than any birds! Can all your worries add a single moment to your life? And if worry can’t accomplish a little thing like that, what’s the use of worrying over bigger things?
 “Look at the lilies and how they grow. They don’t work or make their clothing, yet Solomon in all his glory was not dressed as beautifully as they are. And if God cares so wonderfully for flowers that are here today and thrown into the fire tomorrow, he will certainly care for you. Why do you have so little faith?

 “And don’t be concerned about what to eat and what to drink. Don’t worry about such things. These things dominate the thoughts of unbelievers all over the world, but your Father already knows your needs. Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and he will give you everything you need." Luke 12:22-31 (NLT)

basileia and discipleship these themes are closely related. 
the basileia, even if elusive, provides a vision, an ethic, and a practice for those of us who want to be
disciples.
Basileia, a Greek New Testament term, is usually translated as God’s
'kingdom'. It could be translated as ‘rule’, or the place where God’s active reign is found. But
it’s really about a lifestyle instead of a place, state or empire.
The Old Testament roots of the theme of basileia lie in the idea of Israel
being a theocracy, i.e. a state or country ruled directly by God. lsrael’s
mission was to be a light to the Gentiles, with a vision that Zion would
ultimately be a home for all nations. Here, the reign of Yahweh is
associated with justice, wholeness of nature, abundance, joy, and peace.
It is a time when suffering and war will come to an end.
The Synoptic Gospels present basileia as the key theme of Jesus’
teaching. It is something that can be experienced in the present- even if
only partially- as well as something that will come with the fullness of
time. lt is perhaps because of the Johannine and Pauline writings that
we focus so much on the person of Jesus in our worship, sometimes to
the extent that we forget that Jesus proclaimed the basileia and not
himself.

We can get some idea of what Jesus means by basileia by looking at:
•	three special categories of people — the only groups of whom Jesus
•	said the basileia is theirs already
•	some images of it provided in various parables
l've chosen episodes where Jesus makes comparisons which would
have shocked, and in some cases, amused his audience. They are
illustrations close to their experience — but you should also consider how
different segments of an audience would respond. We’ve got used to
reading these episodes in the Bible where they have been embedded in
the narrative framework created by the Gospel writers. So sometimes it's
very difficult for us to imagine being in an audience hearing these stories
for the first time. Perhaps we’ve become too comfortable in the ways we
read these texts. 

1.	The basileia is for children. 
(Mark 9:35-7, but notice context from 33 on; 10:13-16)
This suggests that the basileia is for the humble and vulnerable. But it
goes a little further than that. In Mediterranean society at the time of
Jesus children had little standing. Thus, Jesus is posing a deliberate
challenge to the disciples. Normally, for the disciples, and probably for
us adults as well, we wouldn’t like being called a child. But this ls
whom Jesus says the basileia is for.
2.	The basileia is for the destitute: ‘BIessed are the ptochoi’.
(Luke 6:20 and Matthew 5:3)  
Usually, ‘ptochoi” is translated as ‘poor’. However, the usual word ln
Greek for ‘poor’ is ‘penes’, which refers to those who, unlike the
extremely wealthy, have to work to live. lt includes those who work as
servants or as labourers in the households or on the estates of the
small aristocratic class. lt also includes the peasant farming family
who has access to land but struggles to make a living from it. A
‘Ptochoi”, meaning ‘one who crouches’, actually means ‘beggar’.
Unlike the ‘poor', the ‘beggar’ lives on the margins of society — a
homeless wanderer without work and without a family to depend on.
In other words, the basileia is for the destitute, those who stand
outside the relationships that govern family and labour for those who
have a social and economic place, however small, in society.
3.	The basileia is for those who are persecuted for their
righteousness. (Matthew 5:10)
Read in conjunction with the Old Testament, this refers to those who
are persecuted because of their commitment to justice. Those in
power, at the receiving end of prophetic criticism, would act against
those who questioned them. ‘

So, this is who the basileia is for, and next we look at what the basileia is described as being.

4.	The basileia is like a weed.
(Mark 4:30-32 = Matthew 13:31-2; Luke13:18-19 = Matthew 13: 31-
32. Matthew 13:24-30 + interpretation in 36-43a)
There are two parables where the basileia is compared to dangerous
plants, the mustard tree (or bush) and darnel —— although we might not
have thought of it in this way.
Many of us will have heard ministers preaching as follows: ‘The
mustard tree has very small seeds. But from this small seed grows a
mighty tree.’ However, in Israel’s view a mighty tree would be the
cedar of Lebanon. 
'The point...is not just that the mustard plant starts as a
proverbially small seed and grows into a shrub of three or
four feet, or even higher, it is that it tends to take over
where it is not wanted, that it tends to get out of control,
and that it tends to attract birds within cultivated areas
where they are not particularly desired; And that, said
Jesus, was what the Kingdom was like: not like the mighty
cedar of Lebanon and not quite like a common weed, like a
pungent shrub with dangerous takeover (i.e. invasive)
properties. Something you would want in only small and
carefully controlled doses - if you could control it.‘
The second story concerns the way in which darnel, a poisonous plant
that looks very much like wheat, grows naturally in wheat fields. The
problem for the rich landowner is how to separate the wheat from the
darnel. In wet years this problem is worse than in dryer years because the
darnel grows more prolifically. The point of this story seems to be that the
landowner and those (servants and labourers) who work the estates are
stuck with this problem, just as they are stuck with the basileia.
Presumably, the landless poor would have enjoyed the point of this tale.
5.	The basileia is like leaven.
(Luke 3:20-1 = Matthew 13:33)
This is the last example l’ll offer. Why would this story offend? Well,
women were subject to purity codes within Jewish law, and so was
leaven - it was regarded as unclean and had to be cleared out of the
household for the duration of the Passover. At the time of Jesus
leaven was made by women by placing a piece of fermenting bread in
a dark place so that the cells of the yeast fungus would develop further
in the bread. Then, small quantities of this leaven would be placed
inside the dough before new bread was baked. What Jesus appears to
have been saying is that the basileia is associated with women and
leaven, both of which were regulated by the religious code of the time.
Both are natural and normal, but society feels uncomfortable. There is
a fear that women and leaven may be corrupting. So, the basileia is
hidden within society or the world much as leaven is hidden in dough.
From here it acts on and brings about a fundamental change - just as
the bread rises.
Thus, in the first three illustrations, the basileia confronts us with God’s
elusive presence. The stories about it and how we can receive it remind
us that it is not through any merit of our own. indeed they illustrate how
God’s love reaches out to those who are most vulnerable, those ‘who
come to God’s presence with empty hands.’ ln
the set of images that follow the basileia is presented as something that
is contagious and invasive, that infects its surroundings. lt cannot be
controlled. ln fact, it discomforts us with its vision that places those on
the margins in our societies at its very centre. its ability to destabilise our
sense of reality and undermine sets of relationships which we take as
normal can be quite terrifying. lt often seems that we can only cope with
small doses of it. Perhaps this is why we so often ignore the economic,
social, and political nature of the claims of God on our lives. We find
them too radical, too egalitarian, too inclusive. Perhaps this is why we
sometimes hasten to insist that small encounters with the basileia are
enough, that this is all we can expect, that it’s future coming in all its
fullness is in the hands of God.

But the challenge of the basileia is not only that it presents us with a
vision of how things could be. lt shows us how things are in the basiliea.
And, if we wish to live faithfully, then we need to live like this as well. So,
even as it critiques our lives against its realities, it provides us with a
social ethic and a social practice that we are called to follow. For many
biblical and theological scholars, this requires us to shift our concern for
‘right teaching’ (orthodoxy) to ‘right practice’ (orthopraxis).
Thus, in CRE, we need to be aware that we are educating people to
participate in the basileia —— it is both the means and the ends of our
discipleship. Some themes which we need to be aware of include:
1. The basileia breaks into our lives as kairos, decisive moments that
require decisions that have profound implications for our lives. The
call to discipleship doesn’t happen only once — each moment of kairos
calls us to make that decision again and again as we consider how to
respond faithfully to new situations.
2. The implication of this first point is that our conversion (metanoia) is
participative and ongoing. It happens in community (koinonia) and it
requires service (diakonia). lt is, in fact, our constant conversion
towards both God and neighbour; my love for God fails when I fail to
love my neighbour. And everyone, including those l see as enemies,
are my neighbours.
3. But these social consequences of the basileia need to be extended
beyond a concern for people and society. The critical question is: Am
I striving to live in love, justice, and peace with the whole of creation?
4. One final point. The Church (ecclesia) exists for the sake of the
basileia, and not the other way around. This subordination of the
church to the basileia means that we have to remember that God is at
work outside of the Church as well. Indeed, in terms of our faith, God
is at work throughout the whole of creation. So, salvation is not the
monopololy of Christians or the Church —— others are able to perform
acts of loving service towards their neighbours without thought of
reward. And, our own perspective is limited. We cannot claim to know
the mind of God and we don’t fully understand just how God is at work
in the world.

One way of gaining insight into discipleship is to use the Gospel of Mark.
Here, the author’s narrative strategy seems to have been that we learn
about discipleship by seeing how hard it is. Thus, the disciples tend to be
shown in a poor light- they are slow to understand, squabble among
themselves, and are jealous of the success of others. The way they are
portrayed in the gospel raises interesting questions:
• How did the Markan community see itself in relation to Jesus’
disciples? .
• How do we understand our relation to this gospel and to the
disciples?
• Are we among those who understand or among those who don’t?
• We might laugh at them — but what about ourselves? Don’t we do
similar things?

Basileia calls us out of our comfort zones, shows us the
injustice in our lives and societies, and the brokeness of creation at the
same time it makes available to us a vision of how things can (and
which faith insists, ultimately will) be different and a set of practices by
which we can, even if only in small ways, anticipate and live out this
difference in our lives. We need to be aware of the ‘signs’ around us
sometimes they call us to loving action on behalf of our neighbour or
creation; at others, they allow a glimpse of the presence and peace of
God.
